utterances: …the eventual stimulus plan that was enacted, got criticism from the left.
They said that the plan was too small.
It got criticism from the right.
They said it was too big.
All this focus was then on the Senate.
But twisting the arms of a few, you know - then he was a Republican, Arlen Specter and the two ladies from Maine, and everyone was unhappy with the final product but that's the product we got.
I think something very similar will happen here with health care.
And is the real battle, do you think, Christopher Hayes, going to be in reconciliation?

That's going to be when the House passes its measure and the Senate passes its measure, and then they try to marry the two in a single committee to present a bill to both houses that would then go to President Obama.
Right.
So, just so that the listeners aren't confused, conference committee, reconciliation is the - you mean, reconciliation in sort of the general sense of reconciling the two…
In reconciling the two bills, yes.
Right.
Yes.
Yes.
So, in conference committee, that is where the, you know, the real - the issue I was just discussing with the previous caller about towards which end of the pole does - do things go.
I mean, I know - and Matt's absolutely right.
The contours of this are identical to the contours over the Recovery Act.
And in that case, you know, the House is able to put in some things that have been taken out by the Senate but largely the bill that came out of conference was tipped towards the Senate.
And the reason was to try to keep those three Republican votes.

One of the questions is, you know, can they get - is - if they're going to do with the reconciliation in which they only need 51 votes, then the center of the gravity, I think, shifts a little bit towards the House.
And so, that's going to play a role into what kind of compromise comes out of conference.
And let me ask you both about timing, both in the short term.
Everybody says if this bill is going to pass it's going to pass this fall.
Matt Continetti, do you agree?
How wonderful.
Thank you, Karen.
At the moment, that's where the political landscape looks like.
I mean, we had a very tumultuous summer.
I think the president was able to calm down some of the tea party movement in terms of creating a public opposition to this bill.
Right now, the numbers have basically settled.
The public is evenly divided, some polls show a little bit more in favor, some other ones show a little bit more opposed.
So, it seems to me, from a conservative standpoint, you know, sadly - but from - if you're the Obama White House yeah, things look, at the moment, pretty good for passage this fall.
Would you agree, Christopher Hayes?
Yeah.
I think if I was - if I were a betting man, I would bet that a health care bill is passed out of both houses and signed this year.
I think that the question is: Is it a good bill?
(Soundbite of laughter)
And I think that that question is not - you know, in the short term, the White House and the Democratic Party need a political victory.

In the long term, it won't be a political victory for long unless it's not a bill that people like, that provides people with health insurance and end some of the worst kind of insurance industry practices and slows the growth of health care inflation.
So, in the short term, it could be a pyrrhic victory if they pass something this fall and get the bump from that and the bill itself doesn't end up delivering on its promise.

Well, it's going to take - even it is passed, it's going to take some years before a lot of the measures take effect, as we were hearing on the - some of the measures in the bill, at least in the Baucus bill -I think in everybody's bill - don't take effect until after the next presidential election, possibly no coincidence.
Convenience.
Yeah.
Yes.
Yeah.
Anyway, gentlemen, thank you so much.
We appreciate your time today.
Christopher Hayes, the Washington editor of The Nation, joined us from that newspaper's offices here in Washington, D.C.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
And Matthew Continetti, associate editor of the Weekly Standard, was with us here in studio 3A.
As always, we appreciate your time.
Thank you, Neal.
Coming up, Kanye, Serena - whatever happened to the art of civility and the art of apology?
Ask Amy's Amy Dickinson joins us next.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Airline travelers tired of standing in long lines waiting to check their bags now have an alternative, at least in some places.
It's called off-site baggage check-in, and it's showing up in cities across America.
We sent DAY TO DAY'S Steve Proffitt out to investigate one remote check-in facility, and here is his report.
(Soundbite of airport PA system)
No waiting permitted.
Loading and unloading only.
This place is called the Van Nuys Flyway, and it's in the San Fernando Valley in the northern part of Los Angeles.

It's essentially a big giant parking lot with a tall parking structure and a lobby where people can bring their bags, check in, get a boarding pass, get on a bus and head for Los Angeles International Airport.
Give us your luggage.
It goes right on your flight and all you have to do when you get to the airport is go through security and to your gate.
Dan Golden works for a private company that has contracts to deliver bags and issue boarding passes for a half dozen major airlines.
His firm charges five dollars per customer for their service.
But there are restrictions: the system doesn't support international travelers and you must be at the site early, often three hours before your scheduled departure.
Simone and Al Meadows are headed from L.A.
to their home in Florida.
They were staying with friends in the San Fernando Valley.
Well, rather than have someone take us down to the airport, we thought this would be a great way to go down.
And then we heard about this service, where we get our boarding passes and just scoot right in.
Sounds pretty good, doesn't it?
It does.
Sounds excellent.
It sounds like a very good idea.
I was saying today, I hope they do it all over.
And in fact, they are.
We also offer service in Boston, New York, Chicago, Miami.
All in all at this time we have 15 cities that we operate out of.
As well as the Hawaiian Islands.
Jose Hernandez is regional director for Baggage Airline Guest Services, or BAGS.
He says theoretically his company can collect bags and issue boarding passes anywhere there is an Internet connection.
And his firm is setting up sites at big resorts, convention centers and the like.
Hernandez says remote check-in sites don't just reduce stress for passengers; they help mitigate strained airline check-in counters at busy airport.
What we're tying to do is relieve those already limited lobby spaces from excess baggage.
Here in the Los Angeles area there are plans for several other remote check-in sites, including one at L.A.'s downtown Union Station.
And if you're wondering about security, here's how it works.
The remotely checked in bags are transported to the airport, taken to a central screening area, and then routed to the proper aircraft.
Bags and other companies that do this kind of thing have to be certified by the transportation security administration.
The companies says your luggage is treated just like it is if you check in at the airport.

Still, even though a service like this might help you avoid struggling with heavy bags through long lines, it can't do anything about the bane of air travelers everywhere: luggage that doesn't arrive at your designation when you do.
For NPR News, I've Steve Proffitt.
If the Conservatives can't deliver, Corbyn said, Labour deserves a chance.
So when I moved to LA in the height of the gang wars in Los Angeles in the '80s, I just was never desensitized to the violence and the ugliness.
And I was trying to produce a movie about amistad, about, you know, us becoming who we are as a people, us being acknowledged as being human, my God, and there we are killing one another.
It just didn't make any sense to me, so I had to get busy.
I had to get - throw my hat in the ring and use everything - every weapon I had.
My weapons are dance and music and film and art.
I think there's some fresh takes on things that I think might take people kind of by surprise.
And one of them is a song ""What Am I Supposed To Do?
Yeah.
It's sung and danced by people in police uniform.
The cops.
The cops - saying you know what am I supposed to do if I see this?
It's one of those things that just makes you sit up and...
And reconsider because you have to face it.
I mean, there's so many really great policemen in our world that are there wearing that badge of honor and courage as they should to protect and defend.
And there are some bad ones.
There's some great doctors.
There's some bad ones that should not be practicing.
There's some wonderful teachers.
There's some bad ones.
There's some great priests.
There's some priests that should not be anywhere around children.
I mean, you could go on and on and on.
There's another monologue I wanted to mention.
It's a monologue by a young basketball star.
Yeah.
